text: They that fear thee will be glad when they see me; because I have hoped in thy word.
text_kjv: They that fear thee will be glad when they see me; because I have hoped in thy word.
text_niv: May those who fear you rejoice when they see me,for I have put my hope in your word.
text_esv: Those who fear you shall see me and rejoice, because I have hoped in your word.
text_nlt: May all who fear you find in me a cause for joy,for I have put my hope in your word.
text_msg: When they see me waiting, expecting your Word,those who fear you will take heart and be glad.
text_nasb: May those who fear You see me and be glad, Because I wait for Your word.
context: Psalm 119 is an acrostic poem, the longest psalm in the Bible, and each of its 176 verses (divided into 22 stanzas of 8 verses each) focuses on the beauty and power of God's law, precepts, statutes, and word. It is believed that the author, traditionally attributed to David, but possibly a later figure steeped in the wisdom tradition of Israel, penned this psalm during a time when faithfulness to God's commandments was paramount. The historical context suggests a period of national instability or personal trial, where adhering to the Law provided stability and direction. The frequent references to 'enemies' highlight the pressures and temptations the psalmist faced to abandon God's path. Understanding that the 'fear of the Lord' was central to Israelite piety is key to interpreting this verse. It encompasses reverence, awe, and obedience to God's commands. Furthermore, 'hope' was not a passive wish, but an active trust and confident expectation that God would fulfill His promises. In ancient Israelite society, a person's reputation and standing within the community were deeply valued. Being seen as righteous and adhering to God's law brought honor and acceptance, whereas deviating from it brought shame and ostracism. The psalmist likely lived within a community of fellow believers who shared this commitment to God's word, offering mutual encouragement and accountability. The 'word' itself was not just a collection of rules, but a source of life, wisdom, and guidance, intimately connected to God's character and covenant with Israel.
meaning: Psalm 119:74 highlights the interconnectedness of faith, community, and the transformative power of hope in God's Word. The phrase 'They that fear thee' refers to individuals who hold God in high reverence and live according to His principles. This 'fear' isn't terror, but a deep respect that motivates obedience and a desire to please God. The psalmist expresses that those who fear God will 'be glad' when they see him. This gladness stems from a shared commitment to God's way and recognition of a fellow believer walking the same path. This joy signifies the encouragement and strength that comes from communal fellowship and mutual support in faith. The psalmist attributes this positive reaction to his 'hope' in God's word. This hope is not wishful thinking, but a firm conviction and confident expectation that God will fulfill His promises and deliver him from his troubles. It speaks to the psalmist's unwavering trust in God's faithfulness and the reliability of His word. His hope is based on the objective truth of God's revealed will, not on subjective feelings or circumstances. The verse also implies the psalmist's life is a testament to the power of God's word. His steadfast obedience and reliance on God's promises have made him a source of encouragement and joy for others who share his faith. He becomes a living example of the benefits of trusting God, demonstrating that hope in God's word leads to a life that is pleasing to God and a blessing to others. It reinforces the idea that personal faith is not lived in isolation but impacts and strengthens the faith of the wider community.
application: In modern times, Psalm 119:74 offers profound guidance for navigating our lives of faith within our communities. Consider how we, as individuals, can embody the hope the psalmist speaks of. Are we actively seeking God's word for guidance and strength? Are we demonstrating a steadfast faith that inspires others to trust in God's promises? Our actions and attitudes should reflect our reliance on God, becoming a beacon of hope for those around us. Furthermore, the verse emphasizes the importance of Christian fellowship. Do we actively seek out and nurture relationships with fellow believers? Do we find joy in their presence and offer them encouragement in their faith journeys? We should intentionally create spaces for mutual support, prayer, and accountability within our church communities, small groups, or even among Christian friends. When we encounter fellow believers, we should strive to be sources of joy and encouragement, recognizing the shared bond we have in Christ. Reflect on how your life might influence others who 'fear' God. Are you living in a way that would bring them gladness upon seeing you, or would your actions cause them to question their own faith? Strive to live a life that reflects the values and principles found in God's word, becoming a positive influence within your sphere of influence. Consider how you can practically demonstrate hope in God's word amidst life's challenges. Do you turn to Scripture for guidance when facing difficult decisions? Do you find comfort and strength in God's promises during times of hardship? By actively engaging with God's word, we can cultivate a resilient hope that sustains us through trials and inspires others to do the same. Remember that the strength of our faith is not solely dependent on individual experience but is fostered and strengthened by our connections with fellow believers. Let us strive to build communities of faith where hope in God's word is celebrated and lived out in practical ways, so that others may find joy and encouragement in our presence.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of your word, a lamp unto my feet and a light unto my path. Help me to cultivate a deep and abiding hope in your promises, a hope that shines brightly in the face of adversity. Lord, fill my heart with reverence for you, that my actions may always be pleasing in your sight. Surround me with fellow believers who share my love for you, and grant us joy in one another's company. May my life be a testament to your faithfulness, so that those who fear you will find encouragement and strength in seeing my devotion. Help me to be a beacon of hope in a world that often feels hopeless. I ask all of this in the name of your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.

faqs.answer: The 'fear of the Lord' is not about being afraid of God in a terrorizing sense. It's a profound reverence, respect, and awe that recognizes His holiness, power, and authority. This fear motivates obedience, humility, and a desire to please God in all aspects of life.

faqs.answer: Their gladness stems from a shared commitment to God's way and recognizing a fellow believer striving for righteousness. It represents the encouragement and strength found in communal fellowship and mutual support within a shared faith.
faqs.question: Why would fellow believers be 'glad' to see the psalmist?

faqs.answer: Hope isn't merely wishful thinking; it is a confident expectation based on the faithfulness of God and the reliability of His word. It is an active trust that God will fulfill His promises and provide deliverance and guidance.
faqs.question: How does 'hope' function in this verse?

faqs.answer: God's 'word' represents His revealed will, commandments, promises, and character. It is the foundation for a righteous life and the source of wisdom, guidance, and comfort. The psalmist sees it as life-giving and transformative.
faqs.question: What is the significance of the psalmist's reliance on God's 'word'?
